page.title: 04 Barham's Nailbourne Stream.
page.content: The Nailbourne is a{small stream}that flows irregularly from Etching Hill, where there is a spring, through Lyminge, Elham, Barham and on towards Kingston.It finally joins the River Stour at West Stourmouth.People believed witches caused the Nailbourne to flow,but we know it is the chalk and clay ground layers that affect it.Rain falls onto the earth and sinks through the chalk layer until it reaches clay, on forming a{water table.}The stream starts to flow when the ground is saturated and the water level is above the valley floor,sometimes disappearing on finding dry chalk,re-emerging when it reaches clay.It flows less frequently today than in the past,but when it does,local people hold races on homemade craft.It flooded in Barham badly in 1937,1960 and again in 1962.
